name: NewYorker
text: The coronavirus pandemic, as has often been noted, oﬀers an opportunity to reopen with a greater recognition of inequalities. For the school system, there is a risk that the reopening process will only amplify those divisions. https://t.co/F7XD6z7N0i

name: NewYorker
text: Zoos still have to feed and care for animals—nearly a million, from 6,000 species in the United States alone—at a time in which revenues have plummeted to nothing, the president of the Association of Zoos and Aquariums said. https://t.co/he9kxWSMl1

name: NewYorker
text: If your vacation is cancelled this year, join two passive-aggressive British comedians eating their way through Lesbos, Athens, and Hydra. https://t.co/bfw6F6MMeO

name: NewYorker
text: “My before-self, before the pandemic, valued her sense of cheerful nihilism,” @EmilyFlake writes. “The tense, watchful person that replaced her is so quick to anger, so quick to cry, so agitated, and so sad.” https://t.co/eUJylKWcJT

name: NewYorker
text: “In society nothing is permanent,” Yuval Noah Harari, the author of “Sapiens,” says. “There’s no essence, no essence to any nation.” In his worldview, many of our daily political struggles barely matter. https://t.co/LoMFhDwfMq

name: NewYorker
text: “This new solitude feels lean and hard. As I move deeper into it, I worry that it will replace all the subtle textures of the solitude into which I’ve grown over the last 30 years.” https://t.co/NcCdL5bvIb

name: NewYorker
text: For the philosopher Søren Kierkegaard, unhappiness was not a condition but a vocation—he called his melancholy “the most faithful mistress I have known.” https://t.co/nREN4oumMH

text: "Today I baked bread, organized my canned goods, and polished all of my exploding gas balls. Again." https://t.co/GVW1UP0YNv

text: Investors are responding to a widely shared narrative that says stock prices tend to rebound sharply after a big fall, an economist said. But stocks don’t always rebound in a “V” shape. https://t.co/uA1FGBry0N

text:
Homelessness aﬄicts nearly one in 500 Americans. “As a crisis, it’s insidious,” @nathanheller writes, “because its victims rarely plunge toward the abyss; they slide.”

name: NewYorker
text: “Who is able to stay at home to do their work and who is not? Who is being given protective gear?” A professor of social epidemiology discusses the inequalities exposed by the coronavirus. https://t.co/PvDQcWF47f

text: Few things are as intoxicating as a Hollywood mystery, and a new documentary about Natalie Wood exacerbates renewed speculation about her shocking death, in 1981. https://t.co/SWEt6rjTR2

text:
In our latest podcast episode, a historian recalls the desperate measures taken to protect children from polio during an epidemic as frightening as our own. Listen here. #NewYorkerRadio
https://t.co/tKinhr5D37

text: “Things boiled that probably would have stayed simmering”: six roommates in a Bushwick house-share discuss the domestic challenges of life under the coronavirus lockdown. https://t.co/uXPdIMeCli

text: Fred Willard, who died recently, was a master at following his instincts, and at inspiring fellow-actors to follow theirs.  https://t.co/V2Hu4s3rn6

text: “Small talk really isn’t small talk, at least not in fiction. Small talk is how characters reveal internal thinking patterns to one other—their processing of the world.” An interview with David Means. https://t.co/SMusswAW77

text: "We don’t have rainy day funds," @peterbachmd says about the American health-care system. "We’re not built for this kind of public need anymore." https://t.co/xEbnQfVt5K

name: NewYorker
text: Frederick Law Olmsted is most beloved for his work on New York City’s Central Park and Prospect Park. But his service to the country during the Civil War is what makes him especially relevant now. https://t.co/3jNDAuEPX6
